content:
First off, the error message may be referring to the total number of recipients you're sending to, so if you send 10 messages / hour, but each message is sent to more than 30 recipients, you may be exceeding the server limits…

Second, this is a server issue, not a Thunderbird issue. The SMTP server, not Thunderbird, is blocking you for (presumably) having abused their sending policies. All Thunderbird is doing is telling you what the SMTP server is telling it…
creator: DavidGG

content:
I'm testing using : Windows 10 OS Thunderbird version 128.8.0 esr

In Settings > Calendar Select a category I do not ever intend to use and click on 'Delete' Did this for a couple.

REopened 'Calendar' and clicked on 'New Event' The deleted categories were no longer available.

Exit Thunderbird - wait few moments forbackground processes to complet - restart Thunderbird. In Calendar - clicked on 'New Event' The deleted categories were not available. Also checked in the Settings > Calendar - Categories The deleted categories were gone and do not return.

Please note those 'Categories' also get used by 'Tasks' So I also selected 'Tasks' to create anew one and check the Categories. They are identical to those in Settings and in New Event selection.

Basically, I do not need to perform any renaming etc. I'm not seeing this issue, but I'm also testing on a more recent version.

You mention using addon extensions that may effect the results. You would need to completely uninstall those addon extensions AND restart Thunderbird in order to be absolutely sure they have been fully removed.

Not sure where you got your installation download of Thunderbird. I got mine some time ago from the official Thunderbird website for the download: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

So not from a Windows app store which means all my profile data etc is stored in the standard default location: C://Users/<username>/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Where did you get your installation of Thunderbird ? Are you storing your profile in the default location or elsewhere ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Good point, maybe these criteria are not part of the header.

Search criterion "Body" doesn't help. Body contents like "Dear Sir or Madam" are found, but none of the highlighted tags or related content (e.g. 8bit, filename, base64,..). Hence body search functions, but apparently unexpectedly limitted.

So if these tags/contents neither belong to body nor to header, how to search for this?

How to determine what Thunderbird identifies as body/header?

Thanks again!
creator: eBeL

content:
eBeL said
How to determine what Thunderbird identifies as body/header?

If you set View/Headers to All, all of, and only, the headers are displayed in the Header Pane. The rest is the body. The message source, Ctrl+U, shows all headers plus the body. So it should be easy to identify header from body.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Well, then the highlighted parts of the source / example are indeed not part of the header. But then the search criterion "Body" doesn't work as expected:

eBeL said

Search criterion "Body" doesn't help. Body contents like "Dear Sir or Madam" are found, but none of the highlighted tags or related content (e.g. 8bit, filename, base64,..). Hence body search functions, but apparently unexpectedly limitted. So if these tags/contents neither belong to body nor to header, how to search for this?
creator: eBeL

content: Body exposes only the HTML as rendered/displayed, not the source of the HTML. Once you accept that you will be a long way to understanding if it is working as designed. Likewise you can not use HTML elements in message filters.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Conclusive.

Quite unfortunate that presumably easily identifiable tags such as Content-Type, Content-Disposition, Content-Transfer-Encoding are not searchable, because they belong to the body. To be honest, I don't see a good reason why these tags belong to body instead of header. Would there be so many message formats to support? The example says muli-part / mixed in MIME format and I wonder how Thunderbird distinguishes between Body and Header.

However, w.r.t. attachments, searching by filenames and filetypes is not possible, but I guess it's a matter of ressources.

It's likely that users would appreciate searching attachments by files (names/types, number,..), not just attachment status or message size.

content: If it's going to spam for one user, it is a local issue for that user. If your messages are going to spam for all your recipients, then it may be something in the content of your message, or that your IP is blacklisted. There is no one explanation.

content:
The following article should help you figure where to look for your profile data. If you can find the profile folder associated with the profile you were using somewhere, then you may restore your mail, because all your mail data was being stored there:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

If that profile folder was stored in an enclosing Profiles folder within a Thunderbird folder, then restoring the whole Thunderbird folder would make things much easier because then you would also restore the profiles.ini file that Thunderbird uses to keep track of your profiles.

If you only have a profile folder that was stored in a non-standard location outside the Thunderbird folder, then you can still restore it, but you'll have to tell Thunderbird where your profile data is by either reusing an existing profile or creating a new profile and make it use the profile folder you have:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles

content: Try this, assuming thunderbird is already installed - exit thunderbird if running - copy and paste the profile folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles - start thunderbird and click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - now, click the 'create profile' button - click next - enter a short name for the profile, such as MYPROFILE -now, click the choose button and locate and select the profile you copied in - click finish and launch If the profile was complete, thunderbird should start. If, instead, you're prompted to create an email account, that indicates the profile has a problem, and the contents may need to be manually copied. Let us know.

content: Email doesn't go to any mail client. It goes to your mail server until a mail client is used to access it. If you see it with one mail client but not the other, it could be because the first mail client that gets to see them removes them from the server, thus making them no longer available to the other…

content:
make sure Thunderbird is not in one of the IMAP folders when it shuts down. On opening it will reach out to the IMAP server to refresh the mail that is listed in the folder, the same as if you clicked on it.

I also suggest that you set Thunderbird to offline mode before you close it down. Nothing stops outreach like being told the internet is not connected.

creator: rustyhaight

content:
If you always want to start Thunderbird in Offline try this: Settings > General scroll to 'Network & Disk Space' section click on 'Offline' button

uncheck 'Automatically follow detected online state' Manual state when starting up: select 'Offline' click on 'OK'


re :ONE of the IMAP accounts started checking email on startup

Maybe that particular server uses PUSH/IDLE eg:Gmail uses PUSH if IDLE is supported and it means gmail will open connection and force the download to allow imap account to reflect up to date situation on server.

This is an explanation of situation: If the three items are disable (not ticked/checked) the account is almost disabled. However, if you select (visit) a folder (e.g., INBOX) any new mail will still be fetched. So to effectively disable an account you have to not select/visit any folder of the account that can receive new mail.

Sounds crazy, I know, but that is the explanation I received. After all, just because you do not want to get messages does not mean you do not want to read messages previously received.

However, there is an addon which may help:

I found this info: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=334483#c45

Filtaquilla - it offers a do not notify option https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/filtaquilla/

content:
If your emails are displaying in the email client called 'Outlook' which is installed on your computer then you could try: In Thunderbird Tools > Import > Import from Outlook - click on 'Continue' and follow instructions.

OR see if Outlook can export the messages in .eml format to a folder on desktop and then use this addon 'ImportExportTools NG' to import those .eml files into 'Local Folders' account. You cannot directly import back into an imap account, but once you have them in Local Folders either leave them in that location or select/highlight emails and use 'Right click' > 'Copy to' > select imap folder. This would upload to server, but you will need to do it in small batches.

Addon called 'ImportExportTools NG' https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/

How to install an addon: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird

To import: Create suitable folder in 'Local Folders' account Right click on that folder and select 'ImportExportTools NG' > 'Import eml messages > 'All eml messages from a directory' and then you get directed to select the folder which contains those eml messages.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I'm going to suggest something based on what someone with a similar problem reported worked for him, without me really understanding why it might work… :)

It looks as if Thunderbird was silently failing to authenticate with the server, without reporting an error message… And it seems that password related problems can sometimes be fixed by removing the password from Thunderbird, even if it is correct, just to make Thunderbird save the password again…

So make sure first that the account is properly set up to authenticate using OAuth2, as described in the following article: https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20

Then proceed as follows:

  1. Go to Settings > Privacy & Security > Saved Passwords.
  2. Look for 'imap', 'smtp' and 'oauth' password entries associated with the account that has the problem, select them and click Remove.
  3. Restart Thunderbird.

Please, post back to report what happens if you try this.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Thank you for the assistance DavidGG. An extraordinary clear and concise walkthrough!

I went through each step to ensure I had the appropriate settings, and the OAuth2 etc., were all set properly prior to this. Glad I confirmed that, though.

The final check for proper authentication tokens appeared to be consistent with the article; however, upon extending the dialogue box to see the full details, there was further info that was unique only to the "failing" secondary email:

oauth://accounts.google.com (https://mail.google.com/ https://www.googleapis.com/auth/carddav https://www.googleapis.com/auth/calendar)

Not sure why this oddity is there, and if it may be the culprit?
creator: jsusanover

content: No, that's correct. Each of the items within parenthesis refers to one of the scopes the OAuth token can be used for (mail, contacts, calendar). You may have that split into more than one OAuth token, but taken together, it should correspond to the things you may see you've granted access to if you check the Security section of your Google account.
creator: DavidGG

content:
I removed all the authentication tokens for the failing email address: oauth, imap, and smtp, and then restarted Thunderbird. That made Thunderbird (and ME!) very happy and brought back the account!

Thank you so much for all your efforts DavidGG! Greatly appreciated!

Sue
creator: jsusanover

content: Great! And thanks for the feedback. Not that I understand why, but now I have confirmation that the suggested procedure can be used to fix this strange problem… :)

content:
Start Thunderbird in Troubleshoot Mode. The following article explains how to do that and why it can be useful to help identify the cause of a problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

Start Windows in Safe Mode with Networking mode. You may have to connect your computer to the router with an Ethernet cable, WiFi is disabled in Safe Mode:

https://support.microsoft.com/help/12376/windows-10-start-your-pc-in-safe-mode

Does any of that make the problem go away? This is how you may know whether the antivirus could be the cause…
creator: DavidGG

content: Hi there Thank you for your suggestions. I have worked out what is causing the slowdown and how to stop the problem though it's not ideal. Bitdefender has an anti-spam filter, which is very useful, once you tell it that an item is spam, it will block all new messages from that address and look for similar messages... However, it doing so, it slows the email system down a lot... So the solution is to turn of the anti-spam part of bitdefender.

content: You typically configure that on the website of the email provider of those other email accounts, using whatever tool they have for that. Nothing to do with Thunderbird, unless you want to set up each of the email accounts in Thunderbird to make it do that, but that wouldn't make much sense…
creator: DavidGG

content: Er zijn twee mogelijkheden: uw provider markeert het bericht als spam, of Thunderbird doet dat. Om het laatste te controleren, kijkt u bij het bericht of het als ongewenst is gemarkeerd middels een vlampictogram. Als dat zo is, klik dan op het vlammetje om de markering op te heffen. Zie Thunderbird en ongewenste of spamberichten. Als uw provider de markering heeft verricht, dan kan het bericht ook in de map Ongewenst (of Spam) belanden. Dit dient u dan via de webmailtoepassing van uw provider te corrigeren.
creator: markh2

content:
The reason you don't appear in 'To:' is probably that you (together with other recipients you cannot see either) are being put in 'Bcc:'. And the reason you cannot stop those messages from being sent to the Spam folder could be that the server, not Thunderbird, is doing that. And then, the latter could be related to the former…

Those messages aren't being marked as junk by Thunderbird, are they? They don't seem to have the banner saying "Thunderbird thinks this message is junk mail"… So it's probably the spam filter at the server, not Thunderbird, what's moving them there before Thunderbird gets to see them.
creator: DavidGG

content: You may run that filter manually whenever you want by selecting the folder and choosing Tools > Run Filters on Folder. Not sure if that's what you're asking…

content: You could do this manually from Classic Search (Ctrl+Shift+F) as in the attached picture. Ctrl+A to select all the search results, then Move to... the desired folder. Save as Search Folder for future operations.

creator: wsmwk

content:
This is a Gmail account, right? Gmail doesn't work like a normal IMAP server would, and one of its many particularities is that mail clients cannot directly remove mail from the All Mail folder. You may accomplish that indirectly by moving the messages to Bin/Trash first (has to be the same Bin/Trash as the one used by Gmail for this to work), and then remove the messages from there or just let Gmail automatically do that after 30 days.

But if you want to remove the messages directly from All Mail, without having to move them to Bin/Trash first, you can only do that from Gmail, cannot do it with Thunderbird or any other mail client.
creator: DavidGG

content: Puzzling. Since 'allmail' is all mail in Gmail, how doe this retention compare to your other gmail message folder settings?
creator: davidsk

content: Right-click on the subfolder and choose Delete. It will be treated according to your settings the same as if it was a message, i.e. moved to Bin/Trash, not deleted immediately, if those are your settings for deleting messages.

content:

creator: DavidGG

content:
Update: issue can be fixed by going into Settings > Fonts & Colors > Advanced

change these settings: Fonts for: Other Writing Systems > set Sans-serif font to Helvetica Fonts for: Latin > set Sans-serif font to Helvetica

the issue seems to have been stemming from using the default font, Lucida Grande
creator: mozillafirebird

content: The issue will stem from using an ansi/ascii font not a unicode font.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Copy the IMAP sent messages to a subfolder of Local Folders, then confirm the copy. The messages are maintained after the IMAP account is removed, and can be copied or moved to any other local folder, including the POP Sent folder.
creator: sfhowes

content: La procedura guidata funziona solo con i provider più comuni o con quello che forniscono la configurazione al client in remoto. Negli altri casi occorre fare la configurazione manuale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/configurazione-manuale-account
creator: @next

content: Aggiungo, per quanto ne so esistono versioni di Thunderbird molto più recente della 24 compatibili con Mac Os 10.13. Per quanto ne so l'ultima versione compatibile è la 115.x
creator: @next

content: The SMTP server probably requires the username used to authenticate to be the same as the 'From:' address of the message being sent. The username shown in your outgoing server settings is not even in the same domain. Do you have more than one account set up with this outgoing server maybe?
creator: DavidGG

content:
It looks like you're trying to send from the bajareque.com account on an smtp with a zaxx.ws User Name. Most providers require the User Name of the sending account to match the User Name of the smtp. Check that you have separate smtp servers defined for each account, and that each account points to the correct smtp.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thanks for the help guys. That worked.
